subsection_content:
To diagnose obesity, doctors will often perform a physical examination and recommend that the patient do some tests (5). These tests often include:
Record your health history. Your doctor will ask about your past weight, weight loss efforts, physical activity and exercise habits, diet and appetite control, other conditions, medications, and stress levels. and other health problems. Doctors can also look at family health history to predict the likelihood of certain diseases.; General health examination including height measurement; check vital indicators such as heart rate, blood pressure and temperature; listen to the heart and lungs, examine the abdomen.; Calculate BMI. A BMI of 30 or higher is considered obese. Everyone should have their BMI checked at least once a year because they can help determine overall health risks and determine appropriate treatment.; Measure your waist. Fat accumulated around the waist, sometimes called visceral fat or belly fat, further increases the risk of heart disease and diabetes. Women with a waist circumference (circumference) greater than 89cm and men with a waist circumference greater than 102cm may have more health risks than people of the same sex with smaller waists. As well as BMI, waist circumference should be measured annually.; Check for other health problems, such as high blood pressure, high cholesterol, underactive thyroid, liver problems, and diabetes.
See more: Causes and signs of obesity in men
